elements.content: All five coordinating atoms of the amino-acid dianion l-aspartate (l-asp = NH2CH­(COO)­CH2COO2–) are found to be involved in coordination with MnII in the presence of [CrIII(CN)6]3– to self-assemble into a chiral three-dimensional cyanide-bridged K3[Mn­(l-asp)]6[Cr­(CN)6]·2H2O containing the highest ratio of Mn:Cr of 6:1. It adopts the chiral P3 (no. 143) space group consisting of zigzag Mn–OCO–Mn chains sharing edges of hexagonal channels with central [Cr­(CN)6]3–, while K+ and H2O occupy another parallel star-shaped channel. Its magnetic susceptibility above 100 K is dominated by the nearest neighbor (Mn–Cr at 5.08 and 5.31 Å) antiferromagnetic (AF) exchange interactions (θ = −15(1) K) and below 40 K by further AF interaction between Mn and Mn at 5.32 Å. It finally reaches a steady value at 4.5 K, where a bifurcation of the zero-field-cooled and field-cooled magnetizations is observed in small fields (<1 kOe). The isothermal magnetization is linear in field and deviating toward saturation above 60 kOe at 2 K. No imaginary component of the ac susceptibilities is observed. This behavior is associated with long-range antiferromagnetic order of a helical or conic nature where the magnetic sublattices are numerous [2n × (6Mn + 1Cr)], leading to a domain of sufficient size to allow for the presence of the bifurcation. A model is proposed based on the local anisotropy and symmetry multiplicity of the space group.
elements.clean_text: All five coordinating atoms of the amino-acid dianion l-aspartate (l-asp = NH2CH(COO)CH2COO2-) are found to be involved in coordination with MnII in the presence of [CrIII(CN)6]3- to self-assemble into a chiral three-dimensional cyanide-bridged K3[Mn(l-asp)]6[Cr(CN)6]⋅2H2O containing the highest ratio of Mn:Cr of 6:1. It adopts the chiral P3 (no. 143) space group consisting of zigzag Mn-OCO-Mn chains sharing edges of hexagonal channels with central [Cr(CN)6]3-, while K+ and H2O occupy another parallel star-shaped channel. Its magnetic susceptibility above 100 K is dominated by the nearest neighbor (Mn-Cr at 5.08 and 5.31 Å) antiferromagnetic (AF) exchange interactions (θ = -15(1) K) and below 40 K by further AF interaction between Mn and Mn at 5.32 Å. It finally reaches a steady value at 4.5 K, where a bifurcation of the zero-field-cooled and field-cooled magnetizations is observed in small fields (<1 kOe). The isothermal magnetization is linear in field and deviating toward saturation above 60 kOe at 2 K. No imaginary component of the ac susceptibilities is observed. This behavior is associated with long-range antiferromagnetic order of a helical or conic nature where the magnetic sublattices are numerous [2n × (6Mn + 1Cr)], leading to a domain of sufficient size to allow for the presence of the bifurcation. A model is proposed based on the local anisotropy and  symmetry multiplicity of the space group.

elements.content: The chiral structure of K3[MnII(l-asp)]6[CrIII(CN)6]·2H2O is generated by five coordination bonds of l-aspartate to MnII and exhibits a novel sequence of CrIII−MnII−MnII−CrIII in this series of compounds. Consequently, it is an antiferromagnet instead of a ferrimagnet and has the lowest critical temperature of 4.5 K. A bifurcation in the zero-field- and field-cooled magnetization below T Néel is associated with a possible chiral soliton lattice generated by either conic or helical moment alignment.
elements.clean_text: The chiral structure of K3[MnII(l-asp)]6[CrIII(CN)6]⋅2H2O is generated by five coordination bonds of l-aspartate to MnII and exhibits a novel sequence of CrIII-MnII-MnII-CrIII in this series of compounds. Consequently, it is an antiferromagnet instead of a ferrimagnet and has the lowest critical temperature of 4.5 K. A bifurcation in the zero-field- and field-cooled magnetization below T Néel is associated with a possible chiral soliton lattice generated by either conic or helical moment alignment.

elements.content: One of the most successful approaches in the design of molecular magnetic materials with high critical temperatures has been the orderly periodic arrangement of two paramagnetic metals carrying different quantum spins. It relies on the fact that (a) the strength of the bonding through the connecting fragments of organic ligands also generate large antiferromagnetic coupling (AF) between nearest neighbor magnetic centers and (b) these interaction pathways are of high dimensionality. Furthermore, since the strength of the AF coupling depends on the number of nonmagnetic atoms making the connection between the magnetic metal centers, the organic ligand is usually kept simple and therefore the favorites are those forming M–O–M′, M–N–M′, M–N–N–M′, M–C–N–M′, M–O–C–O–M′, and M–N–C–N–M′ bridges; thus, cyanide, azide, and carboxylate are very commonly used. Other functionalities, such as chirality, nonlinear optics, luminescence, and photoreactive components, can be introduced through the backbone of the ligands carrying the above groups. Our group has been exploring such an approach successfully to introduce structural chirality in the search for dual properties involving chirality and magnetic ordering. We and other researchers have therefore synthesized a large variety of chiral molecular magnets. Our original and continuing approach is to use small chiral ligands with varying number of coordinating atoms (). The results are quite informative. First, a variety of crystal systems, hexagonal, monoclinic, and orthorhombic, are observed. Second, the ratio of the number of the two magnetic metals (Mn and Cr) is variable. Third, the magnetic order is invariably ferrimagnetic with critical temperatures falling in two ranges: (a) 36–38 and (b) 35–53 K. Progressing in this approach our choice of ligand l-aspartate for the present work was made on the number of potential coordinating atoms (five in total, four oxygen from carboxylate, and one nitrogen from the amine ()) which is the highest used so far. It turns out to be a nonconformer with previous observations: (a) it has the highest Mn:Cr ratio of 6:1, (b) it is the first to exhibit long-range antiferromagnetic ordering, (c) the critical temperature is the lowest at 4.5 K compared to the ordered magnets (35–53 K), and (d) it displays an unexpected bifurcation between ZFC and FC for an antiferromagnet below T N which is possibly due to domains consisting of chiral solitons. Here, we report its synthesis, crystal structure at different temperatures (93–293 K), and magnetic properties as a function of temperature, field, and ac frequency.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

One of the most successful approaches in the design of molecular magnetic materials with high critical temperatures has been the orderly periodic arrangement of two paramagnetic metals carrying different quantum spins. It relies on the fact that (a)  the strength of the bonding through the connecting fragments of organic ligands also generate large antiferromagnetic coupling (AF) between nearest neighbor magnetic centers and (b)  these interaction pathways are of high dimensionality. Furthermore, since the strength of the AF coupling depends on the number of nonmagnetic atoms making the connection between the magnetic metal centers, the organic ligand is usually kept simple and therefore the favorites are those forming M-O-M', M-N-M', M-N-N-M', M-C-N-M', M-O-C-O-M', and M-N-C-N-M' bridges; thus, cyanide, azide, and carboxylate are very commonly used. Other functionalities, such as chirality, nonlinear optics, luminescence, and photoreactive components, can be introduced through the backbone of the ligands carrying the above groups. Our group has been exploring such an approach successfully to introduce structural chirality in the search for dual properties involving chirality and magnetic ordering. We and other researchers have therefore synthesized a large variety of chiral molecular magnets. Our original and continuing approach is to use small chiral ligands with varying number of coordinating atoms (). The results are quite informative. First, a variety of crystal systems, hexagonal, monoclinic, and orthorhombic, are observed. Second, the ratio of the number of the two magnetic metals (Mn and Cr) is variable. Third, the magnetic order is invariably ferrimagnetic with critical temperatures falling in two ranges: (a) 36-38 and (b) 35-53 K. Progressing in this approach our choice of ligand l-aspartate for the present work was made on the number of potential coordinating atoms (five in total, four oxygen from carboxylate, and one nitrogen from the amine ()) which is the highest used so far. It turns out to be a nonconformer with previous observations: (a) it has the highest Mn:Cr ratio of 6:1, (b) it is the first to exhibit long-range antiferromagnetic ordering, (c) the critical temperature is the lowest at 4.5 K compared to the ordered magnets (35-53 K), and (d) it displays an unexpected bifurcation between ZFC and FC for an antiferromagnet below T N which is possibly due to domains consisting of chiral solitons. Here, we report its synthesis, crystal structure at different temperatures (93-293 K), and  magnetic properties as a function of temperature, field, and ac frequency.

elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Molecular Structure of the Aspartate Ion Showing the Involvement of Its Five Peripheral Atoms through Coordination to Four Mn(II) in K3[Mn(l-asp)]6[Cr(CN)6]⋅2H2O through One Five-Membered Ring Chelate (O and N) and One Syn-Anti and One Anti-Anti Carboxylate; (b) Observed Coordination of Aspartate Bridging the Metals within One Chain and between Adjacent Chains

elements.content: All manipulations were performed under an argon atmosphere to avoid the oxidation of MnII ions. Crystals of K3[Mn­(l-asp)]6[Cr­(CN)6]·2H2O were prepared by slow diffusion as follows: 1 mL of an aqueous solution of l-aspartic acid (2 mmol), KOH (3.2 mmol), and K3[Cr­(CN)6] (0.1 mmol) was placed in a 25 cm long glass tube (ϕ = 5 mm) followed by 1 mL of a H2O:EtOH (3:1) mixture as buffer and a top layer of a solution of 1.5 mL of H2O:EtOH (1:3) containing MnCl2·4H2O (3 mmol). After 2 months, undisturbed in the dark, orange hexagonal prism crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiment were obtained. Anal. Calcd for K3[Mn­(l-asp)]6[Cr­(CN)6]·2H2O, C30H34CrK3Mn6N12O26: C, 24.39; H, 2.32; N, 11.38. Found: C, 23.80; H, 2.04; N, 11.86.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All manipulations were performed under an argon atmosphere to avoid the oxidation of MnII ions. Crystals of K3[Mn(l-asp)]6[Cr(CN)6]⋅2H2O were prepared by slow diffusion as follows: 1 mL of an aqueous solution of l-aspartic acid (2 mmol), KOH (3.2 mmol), and K3[Cr(CN)6] (0.1 mmol) was placed in a 25 cm long glass tube (ϕ = 5 mm) followed by 1 mL of a H2O:EtOH (3:1) mixture as buffer and a top layer of a solution of 1.5 mL of H2O:EtOH (1:3) containing MnCl2⋅4H2O (3 mmol). After 2 months, undisturbed in the dark, orange hexagonal prism crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiment were obtained. Anal. Calcd for K3[Mn(l-asp)]6[Cr(CN)6]⋅2H2O, C30H34CrK3Mn6N12O26: C, 24.39; H, 2.32; N, 11.38. Found: C, 23.80; H, 2.04; N, 11.86.

elements.content:
Caution! Cyanide-containing compounds are toxic and should be handled very carefully in only small amounts.

Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out using a PerkinElmer series II CHNS/O Analyzer 2400 at the Natural Science Center for Basic Research and Development (N-BARD), Hiroshima University. TGA was measured under a flow of nitrogen gas at a heating rate of 5 K/min by use of a SII EXSTAR TGA. Infrared spectra were recorded by transmission through a KBr crystal smeared with fine powder of the compounds on a JASCO FT/IR-660 PLUS.
elements.clean_text:
Caution! Cyanide-containing compounds are toxic and should be handled very carefully in only small amounts. 

Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out using a PerkinElmer series II CHNS/O Analyzer 2400 at the Natural Science Center for Basic Research and Development (N-BARD), Hiroshima University. TGA was measured under a flow of nitrogen gas at a heating rate of 5 K/min by use of a SII EXSTAR TGA. Infrared spectra were recorded by transmission through a KBr crystal smeared with fine powder of the compounds on a JASCO FT/IR-660 PLUS.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction measurements were performed using a Bruker SMART-APEX II diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector and graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at the Natural Science Center for Basic Research and Development (N-BARD), Hiroshima University. The diffraction data were collected at 93, 143, 193, 243, and 293 K using a ω-scan mode (0.5° steps). The structures were solved by standard direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares against F 2 of all data using SHELX-97. Hydrogen atoms from crystal water were not included in calculated positions because they were absent in the difference Fourier map. All atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters except for hydrogen atoms.
elements.clean_text: X-ray diffraction measurements were performed using a Bruker SMART-APEX II diffractometer equipped with a CCD area detector and graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at the Natural Science Center for Basic Research and Development (N-BARD), Hiroshima University. The diffraction data were collected at 93, 143, 193, 243, and 293 K using a ω-scan mode (0.5° steps). The structures were solved by standard direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares against F 2 of all data using SHELX-97. Hydrogen atoms from crystal water were not included in calculated positions because they were absent in the difference Fourier map. All  atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters except for hydrogen atoms.

elements.content: The dc and ac magnetization measurements were carried out using Quantum Design MPMS-5S and MPMS-XL7 SQUID magnetometers, respectively. The diamagnetic correction was estimated from Pascal constants to be 7.9076 × 10–4 emu mol–1.
elements.clean_text: The dc and ac magnetization measurements were carried out using Quantum Design MPMS-5S and MPMS-XL7 SQUID magnetometers, respectively. The diamagnetic correction was estimated from Pascal constants to be 7.9076 × 10-4 emu mol-1.

elements.content: The key feature of the structure (), belonging to the chiral P3 space group, is the formation of six zigzag Mn1–OCO–Mn2 chains forming a network of interlocked hexagonal and “Star of David” channels where the [Cr­(CN)6] occupies the former and the K+ and H2O the latter. The Mn chains are slightly rotated about the c axis in the same sense that generates the chirality of the framework. The [Cr­(CN)6] are disordered on two identical sites with 50% occupancy, an effect not found for related cyanide-bridge compounds, and they are slightly compressed about the c axis, while the cyanide groups connect the Mn atoms of the six peripheral chains. K+ and H2O are also disordered with partial occupancy with the potassium having a coordination number of 6. The 2-fold disorder was first considered to be due to twinning, and three more crystals were examined giving the same results. We therefore considered it is intrinsic to this crystal structure. Attempts to solve the structure in different space groups were not successful. In this compound, as in the related materials, the principal function of the organic ligands is their coordination to the Mn atoms and imposing the chosen chirality. In the present case all possible coordinating atoms (five in total, 4 O and 1 N, comprising two carboxylate and one amine) of the aspartate are involved in coordination and thus is the highest so far in this branch of research. One oxygen atom of the carboxylate and the amine are chelated to Mn1 and the carboxylate bridges Mn1 and Mn2 from adjacent chains of Mn in an anti-anti mode (). The second carboxylate also bridges Mn1 and Mn2 but from one single Mn chain and adopts a syn-anti mode of coordination. We believe that due to the high coordination of the aspartate and the 1:1 stoichiometric ratio of l-aspartate:MnII, the number of Mn to Cr is also high (6:1) compared to a lower number for ligands with low coordinating atoms used previously. Thus, only one cyanide group is coordinated to each Mn.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure

The key feature of the structure (), belonging to the chiral P3 space group, is the formation of six zigzag Mn1-OCO-Mn2 chains forming a network of interlocked hexagonal and "Star of David" channels where the [Cr(CN)6] occupies the former and the K+ and H2O the latter. The Mn chains are slightly rotated about the c axis in the same sense that generates the chirality of the framework. The [Cr(CN)6] are disordered on two identical sites with 50% occupancy, an effect not found for related cyanide-bridge compounds, and they are slightly compressed about the c axis, while the cyanide groups connect the Mn atoms of the six peripheral chains.  K+ and H2O are also disordered with partial occupancy with the potassium having a coordination number of 6. The 2-fold disorder was first considered to be due to twinning, and three more crystals were examined giving the same results. We therefore considered it is intrinsic to this crystal structure. Attempts to solve the structure in different space groups were not successful. In this compound, as in the related materials, the principal function of the organic ligands is their coordination to the Mn atoms and imposing the chosen chirality. In the present case all  possible coordinating atoms (five in total, 4 O and 1 N, comprising two carboxylate and one amine) of the aspartate are involved in coordination and thus is the highest so far in this branch of research. One oxygen atom of the carboxylate and the amine are chelated to Mn1 and the carboxylate bridges Mn1 and Mn2 from adjacent chains of Mn in an anti-anti mode (). The second carboxylate also bridges Mn1 and Mn2 but from one single Mn chain and adopts a syn-anti mode of coordination. We believe that due to the high coordination of the aspartate and the 1:1 stoichiometric ratio of l-aspartate:MnII, the number of Mn to Cr is also high (6:1) compared to a lower number for ligands with low coordinating atoms used previously. Thus, only one cyanide group is coordinated to each Mn.

elements.content: Several metrics that are important for the stabilization of this particular structure are also relevant to the observed magnetism (see later). These metrics are slightly temperature dependent. First is the connection of Cr to Mn via the cyanide bridge where the distances are 5.08 and 5.31 Å above and below the ab plane containing the Cr, respectively. The angles are 176.4° (Cr–CN), 133.6° (CN–Mn1), and 145.5° (CN–Mn2). The difference between the latter two angles is due to the slight compression of the [CrIII(CN)6]3– octahedron leading to a slight displacement of the Cr from the center of the octahedron resulting in two Cr–C distances of 2.070 and 2.077 Å. The departure from perfect octahedral geometry has been observed for several other related materials and more pronounced for the Jahn–Teller ion [MnIII(CN)6]3–. Due to this asymmetry in the [Cr­(CN)6]3– octahedron, there are two sets of parameters for the first and second spheres of Mn neighbors that are 5.08 (Cr–Mn1) and 5.31 Å (Cr–Mn2) and 8.51 and 10.39 (Cr–Mn2–Mn1) and 8.65 and 10.04 Å (Cr–Mn1–Mn2), respectively. The nearest Cr–Cr distance is 7.84 Å. There is only one Mn1–Mn2 distance of 5.32 Å via Mn–OCO–Mn and the nearest distances within the Mn chains are almost similar at 6.81 Å for Mn1–Mn1 and Mn2–Mn2 that are connected through Mn–OCCCCO–Mn.
elements.clean_text: Several metrics that are important for the stabilization of this particular structure are also relevant to the observed magnetism (see later). These metrics are slightly temperature dependent. First is the connection of Cr to Mn via the cyanide bridge where the distances are 5.08 and 5.31 Å above and below the ab plane containing the Cr, respectively. The angles are 176.4° (Cr-CN), 133.6° (CN-Mn1), and 145.5° (CN-Mn2). The difference between the latter two angles is due to the slight compression of the [CrIII(CN)6]3- octahedron leading to a slight displacement of the Cr from the center of the octahedron resulting in two Cr-C distances of 2.070 and 2.077 Å. The departure from perfect octahedral geometry has been observed for several other related materials and  more pronounced for the Jahn-Teller ion [MnIII(CN)6]3-. Due to this asymmetry in the [Cr(CN)6]3- octahedron, there are two sets of parameters for the first and second spheres of Mn neighbors that are 5.08  (Cr-Mn1) and 5.31 Å (Cr-Mn2) and 8.51 and 10.39  (Cr-Mn2-Mn1) and 8.65 and 10.04 Å (Cr-Mn1-Mn2), respectively. The nearest Cr-Cr distance is 7.84 Å. There is only one Mn1-Mn2 distance of 5.32 Å via Mn-OCO-Mn and the nearest distances within the Mn chains are almost similar at 6.81 Å for Mn1-Mn1 and Mn2-Mn2 that are connected through Mn-OCCCCO-Mn.

elements.content: Crystal structure of K3[Mn­(l-asp)]6[Cr­(CN)6]·2H2O: (a) coordination of the two independent Mn­(II), (b) zigzag chains of Mn­(II)–asp, and (c) hexagonal packing of the chains with the [Cr­(CN)6] connected to them through the cyanide in the hexagonal channels and the K and H2O in the Star of David channels.
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of K3[Mn(l-asp)]6[Cr(CN)6]⋅2H2O: (a)  coordination of the two independent Mn(II), (b)  zigzag chains of Mn(II)-asp, and (c)  hexagonal packing of the chains with the [Cr(CN)6] connected to them through the cyanide in the hexagonal channels and the K and H2O in the Star of David channels.

elements.content: We studied the temperature dependence of the crystal structure in searching of any anomaly that may occur (, and S1). However, while there are changes taking place they seem to be only associated with the thermal contraction of the lattice but hardly any noticeable change on the molecular scale.

However, while there are changes taking place they seem to be only associated with the thermal contraction of the lattice but hardly any noticeable change on the molecular scale.

I ≥ 2σ­(I).

All data.

The thermogravimetric analysis on heating under a flow of dry nitrogen shows almost a constant weight until 100 °C followed by a loss of two water molecules per mole by 220 °C (Figure S1). Between 220 and 320 °C the loss of weight amounts to the departure of the aspartate. Further heating leads to continuous weight loss. The observed loss of two water molecules was helpful in the final refinement of the X-ray crystal structure determination that accounts for the remaining electron density after the metal–cyanide framework was established.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Property

The thermogravimetric analysis on heating under a flow of dry nitrogen shows almost a constant weight until 100 °C followed by a loss of two water molecules per mole by 220 °C (Figure S1). Between 220 and 320 °C the loss of weight amounts to the departure of the aspartate. Further heating leads to continuous weight loss. The observed loss of two water molecules was helpful in the final refinement of the X-ray crystal structure determination that accounts for the remaining electron density after the metal-cyanide framework was established.

elements.content: The infrared spectra of the compound and the starting materials have been recorded by transmission through KBr crystals that have been smeared with the crushed fine powders of the compound (Figure S2). The spectrum of the Mn–Cr compound is as expected and contains the vibration of aspartate where the asymmetric and symmetric carboxylate bands have been lowered in energy upon coordination to the manganese atom compared to those of the free acid. The low-energy bands correspond to those of the free acid and the metal cyano complex. In contrast at high energy, there are sharp N–H and C–H bands corresponding to the aspartate group and broad O–H from the water of crystallization. While there is only one antisymmetric stretching band of the chromium hexacyanide at 2130 cm–1, three peaks are observed when it is coordinated to the Mn in the framework at 2124, 2140, and 2148 cm–1, which is related to the lowering of symmetry from O h upon coordination.
elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectroscopy

The infrared spectra of the compound and the starting materials have been recorded by transmission through KBr crystals that have been smeared with the crushed fine powders of the compound (Figure S2). The spectrum of the Mn-Cr compound is as expected and contains the vibration of aspartate where the asymmetric and symmetric carboxylate bands have been lowered in energy upon coordination to the manganese atom compared to those of the free acid. The low-energy bands correspond to those of the free acid and the metal cyano complex. In contrast at high energy, there are sharp N-H and C-H bands corresponding to the aspartate group and broad O-H from the water of crystallization. While there is only one antisymmetric stretching band of the chromium hexacyanide at 2130 cm-1, three peaks are observed when it is coordinated to the Mn in the framework at 2124, 2140, and 2148 cm-1, which is related to the lowering of symmetry from O  h  upon coordination.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of the χm T (red) and its inverse (blue) for K3[Mn­(l-asp)]6[Cr­(CN)6]·2H2O. Solid lines are the Curie–Weiss fits between 150 and 300 K, extended to low temperatures.
elements.clean_text: 3  Temperature dependence of the χm T (red) and its inverse (blue) for K3[Mn(l-asp)]6[Cr(CN)6]⋅2H2O. Solid lines are the Curie-Weiss fits between 150 and 300 K, extended to low temperatures.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibility was measured for a sample of randomly oriented crystals () in a field of 1 kOe. Above 120 K the data behave in a Curie–Weiss fashion with Curie constant C = 27.06(3) emu K/mol and Weiss temperature θ = −15(1) K. The Curie constant is close to the expected value of 28.12 emu K/mol–1 for the sum of those of six MnII and one CrIII. The negative value of the Weiss temperature suggests antiferromagnetic coupling between nearest neighbors (Cr–Mn) consistent with those found for known materials of the kind. Below 120 K, it deviates due to the noncompensation of moments of the two carriers Mn (d5, S = 5/2) and Cr (d3, S = 3/2). This deviation from Curie–Weiss behavior is reflected by a minimum in the temperature dependence of the effective moment represented as χT versus T at ca. 120 K. This behavior is consistent with that observed for the [CrIII{CNMnII(tetren)}6]2[MnII(tetren)­(H2O)]2(ClO4)22 and [CrIII{CNMnII(dmptacn)}6] [CrIII(CN)6]­(ClO4)6·6H2O where the Cr–Mn exchange interaction is estimated to be −9 and −5 cm–1, respectively. However, for the former the magnetization tends toward the expected effective moment of 97.9 emu K/mol at low temperatures, but for the present case the effective moment exhibits a maximum of 31.2 emu K/mol at 28 K and reaches 5.24 emu K/mol at 2 K. This is a clear indication of antiferromagnetic exchange between CrMn6 clusters via the Mn–OCO–Mn connection.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The magnetic susceptibility was measured for a sample of randomly oriented crystals () in a field of 1 kOe. Above 120 K the data behave in a Curie-Weiss fashion with Curie constant C = 27.06(3) emu K/mol and Weiss temperature θ = -15(1) K. The Curie constant is close to the expected value of 28.12 emu K/mol-1 for the sum of those of six MnII and one CrIII. The negative value of the Weiss temperature suggests antiferromagnetic coupling between nearest neighbors (Cr-Mn) consistent with those found for known materials of the kind. Below 120 K, it deviates due to the noncompensation of moments of the two carriers Mn (d5, S = 5/2) and Cr (d3, S = 3/2). This deviation from Curie-Weiss behavior is reflected by a minimum in the temperature dependence of the effective moment represented as χT versus T at ca. 120 K. This behavior is consistent with that observed for the [CrIII{CNMnII(tetren)}6]2[MnII(tetren)(H2O)]2(ClO4)22 and [CrIII{CNMnII(dmptacn)}6] [CrIII(CN)6](ClO4)6⋅6H2O where the Cr-Mn exchange interaction is estimated to be -9 and -5 cm-1, respectively. However, for the former the magnetization tends toward the expected effective moment of 97.9 emu K/mol at low temperatures, but for the present case the effective moment exhibits a maximum of 31.2 emu K/mol at 28 K and reaches 5.24 emu K/mol at 2 K. This is a clear indication of antiferromagnetic exchange between CrMn6 clusters via the Mn-OCO-Mn connection.

elements.content: (a) Field dependence of the ZFC-FC susceptibility and (b) ac and dc magnetic susceptibilities of K3[Mn­(l-asp)]6[Cr­(CN)6]·2H2O.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Field dependence of the ZFC-FC susceptibility and (b) ac and dc magnetic susceptibilities of K3[Mn(l-asp)]6[Cr(CN)6]⋅2H2O.

elements.content: At 4.5 K there is an anomaly where the susceptibility reaches a constant value in fields up to 2 kOe (). The appearance of this feature is unusual in the field of molecular magnetism. Further exploration of this anomaly by a zero-field- and field-cooled protocol reveals a bifurcation exists below 4.5 K, and the degree of bifurcation diminishes progressively as the field is increased to 1 kOe. The susceptibility is very weakly dependent on the applied field in the range 0–1 kOe. Since the magnetization does not show a sharp increase, this transition is therefore not consistent with either a ferromagnetic or a canted antiferromagnetic ground state. Further measurements using ac field show only a real component of the ac susceptibilities that has a temperature dependence similar to the dc susceptibility in zero-field-cooling mode. There is neither an imaginary component nor a frequency dependence of the ac susceptibilities.
elements.clean_text: At 4.5 K there is an anomaly where the susceptibility reaches a constant value in fields up to 2 kOe (). The appearance of this feature is unusual in the field of molecular magnetism. Further exploration of this anomaly by a zero-field- and field-cooled protocol reveals a bifurcation exists below 4.5 K, and the degree of bifurcation diminishes progressively as the field is increased to 1 kOe. The susceptibility is very weakly dependent on the applied field in the range 0-1 kOe. Since the magnetization  does not show a sharp increase, this transition is therefore not consistent with either a ferromagnetic or a canted antiferromagnetic ground state. Further measurements using ac field show only a real component of the ac susceptibilities that has a temperature dependence similar to the dc susceptibility in zero-field-cooling mode. There is neither an imaginary component nor a frequency dependence of the ac susceptibilities.

elements.content: Isothermal magnetization as a function of applied field at three different temperatures of 2, 5, and 10 K () shows linear dependence in the field range ±50 kOe. Beyond 50 kOe, it deviates from linearity and reaches 26 μB at 2 K, close to the expected saturation moment of 27 μB assuming g = 2. For those at 5 and 10 K the curvature is less pronounced. The deviation may be associated with the anisotropic field (H A) of an antiferromagnet.
elements.clean_text: Isothermal magnetization as a function of applied field at three different temperatures of 2, 5, and 10 K () shows linear dependence in the field range ±50 kOe. Beyond 50 kOe, it deviates from linearity and reaches 26 μB at 2 K, close to the expected saturation moment of 27 μB assuming g = 2. For those at 5 and 10 K the curvature is less pronounced. The deviation may be associated with the anisotropic field (H A) of an antiferromagnet.

elements.content: Field dependence isothermal magnetization of K3[Mn­(l-asp)]6[Cr­(CN)6]·2H2O above (5 and 10 K) and below (2 K) T Néel (4.5 K). Solid lines are the magnetization calculated by the Brillouin function for S = 27/2 (blue) and six isolated Mn2+ ions and one Cr3+ ion (gray) at 2 K.

Solid lines are the magnetization calculated by the Brillouin function for S = 27/2 (blue) and six isolated Mn2+ ions and one Cr3+ ion (gray) at 2 K.

elements.content: While the magnetic properties of this compound at high temperatures (≥10 K) can be accounted for using a normal analysis procedure, the behavior below 5 K is quite unusual due to its very weak temperature dependence and nonequivalence of the zero-field- and field-cooled magnetizations in low fields. The observations indicate there is neither a spontaneous magnetization for it to be a ferromagnet or a canted antiferromagnet nor a reduction as expected for a colinear antiferromagnet. The lack of imaginary component of the ac susceptibilities eliminates the former two possibilities. The absence of any abrupt change of the isothermal magnetization eliminates metamagnetism. However, the type of anomaly has been found to be associated with spin glass systems where the moment carriers are dilute and crystallographically disordered. In contrast, the carriers in the present case are not dilute, and they belong to a crystallographically ordered state except for the statistical disorder of the Cr center on two crystallographically equivalent sites. Therefore, three important questions remain: What is the magnetic ground state of this compound, why is the critical transition temperature (4.5 K) lower than all known Mn–Cr systems (30–90 K), and why it is not a ferrimagnet as all the others?
elements.clean_text: While the magnetic properties of this compound at high temperatures (≥10 K) can be accounted for using a normal analysis procedure, the behavior below 5 K is quite unusual due to its very weak temperature dependence and nonequivalence of the zero-field- and field-cooled magnetizations in low fields. The observations indicate there is neither a spontaneous magnetization for it to be a ferromagnet or a canted antiferromagnet nor a reduction as expected for a colinear antiferromagnet. The lack of imaginary component of the ac susceptibilities eliminates the former two possibilities. The absence of any abrupt change of the isothermal magnetization eliminates metamagnetism. However, the type of anomaly has been found to be associated with spin glass systems where the moment carriers are dilute and crystallographically disordered. In contrast, the carriers in the present case are not dilute, and they belong to a crystallographically ordered state except for the statistical disorder of the Cr center on two crystallographically equivalent sites. Therefore, three important questions remain: What is the magnetic ground state of this compound, why is the critical transition temperature (4.5 K) lower than all  known Mn-Cr systems (30-90 K), and why it is not a ferrimagnet as all the others?

elements.content: For the first question, considering the crystal structure we can rationalize the magnetic behavior by taking the two important nearest-neighbor exchange interactions, J(Cr–Mn) and J(Mn–Mn). The first is expected to be larger due to the exchange through high electron density cyanide, and from previous studies as well as taking the electronic configuration into account it is antiferromagnetic. Since J(Cr–Mn) only operates within each CrMn6 cluster it will result in a ferrimagnetic unit with an effective S = 27/2 (6 × 5/2 – 3/2) as has been demonstrated for isolated clusters. Further interaction between these units through the weak antiferromagnetic J(Mn–Mn) will lead to a fully compensated antiferromagnet. We therefore assign the anomaly at 4.5 K to long-range antiferromagnetic order. The constant susceptibility below T N suggests the orientations of the moments are not colinear. A potential magnetic structure will be where the moment of Cr points along the c axis due to the slight anisotropy and the Dzyaloshinsky–Moriya interaction imposed by the distortion of the octahedron discussed earlier and those of the Mn aligned in a cone or in a helix. Given that there are 7 moment carriers per unit and needing two of them for an antiferromagnetic state, there will be a minimum of 14 magnetic sublattices. In addition, to account for the minimum multiplicity of 3 imposed by the space group a minimum of 42 magnetic sublattices will be required. Such a large number of moments may be sufficient to generate an antiferromagnetic domain or a chiral soliton. We believe this is the reason for the difference in ZFC and FC magnetization below T N.
elements.clean_text: For the first question, considering the crystal structure we can rationalize the magnetic behavior by taking the two important nearest-neighbor exchange interactions, J(Cr-Mn) and J(Mn-Mn). The first is expected to be larger due to the exchange through high electron density cyanide, and from previous studies as well as taking the electronic configuration into account it is antiferromagnetic. Since J(Cr-Mn) only operates within each CrMn6 cluster it will result in a ferrimagnetic unit with an effective S = 27/2 (6 × 5/2 - 3/2) as has been demonstrated for isolated clusters. Further interaction between these units through the weak antiferromagnetic J(Mn-Mn) will lead to a fully compensated antiferromagnet. We therefore assign the anomaly at 4.5 K to long-range antiferromagnetic order. The constant susceptibility below T N suggests the orientations of the moments are not colinear. A potential magnetic structure will be where the moment of Cr points along the c axis due to the slight anisotropy and the Dzyaloshinsky-Moriya interaction imposed by the distortion of the octahedron discussed earlier and those of the Mn aligned in a cone or in a helix. Given that there are 7 moment carriers per unit and needing two of them for an antiferromagnetic state, there will be a minimum of 14 magnetic sublattices. In addition, to account for the minimum multiplicity of 3 imposed by the space group a minimum of 42 magnetic sublattices will be required. Such a large number of moments may be sufficient to generate an antiferromagnetic domain or a chiral soliton. We believe this is the reason for the difference in ZFC and FC magnetization below T N.

elements.content: Concerning the low Néel temperature we need to go back to the crystal structure and compare the metrics of the Cr–CN–Mn connection that involves the principal magnetic interaction for the series of related compounds (). In most cases the Cr–CN angles are close to being linear but that of CN–Mn varies from 180° to 133°. When the latter is 180° the compounds have the highest T C of 90 K for the 3D Prussian Blue analogue. For intermediate average angle of 165° T C falls in the range 35–50 K. In line with this trend the present compound has the lowest angle of 133° and 145°, which resulted in the lowest critical temperature of 4.5 K. In this analysis, the weak antiferromagnetic interaction, J(MnII–OCO–MnII), also contributes to the 3D ordering of the moments and is not to be ignored.
elements.clean_text: Concerning the low Néel temperature we need to go back to the crystal structure and compare the metrics of the Cr-CN-Mn connection that involves the principal magnetic interaction for the series of related compounds (). In most cases the Cr-CN angles are close to being linear but that of CN-Mn varies from 180° to 133°. When the latter is 180° the compounds have the highest T C of 90 K for the 3D Prussian Blue analogue. For intermediate average angle of 165° T C falls in the range 35-50 K. In line with this trend the present compound has the lowest angle of 133° and 145°, which resulted in the lowest critical temperature of 4.5 K. In this analysis, the weak antiferromagnetic interaction, J(MnII-OCO-MnII), also contributes to the 3D ordering of the moments and is not to be ignored.

elements.content: An answer to the final question regarding the type of long-range magnetic order is related to the sequence of the two moment carriers in the lattice. When the sequence is ···Cr–Mn–Cr–Mn··· in two or three dimension, as is the case for all previously studied systems, the ground state is ferrimagnetic, meaning a magnetic order ↑ ↓ ↑ ↓ (where ↑ and ↓ represent the moment vector of Cr (3 μB) and Mn (5 μB), respectively). For the present compound the sequence is···Cr–Mn–Mn–Cr···, and for an all AF couplings of the moments will arrange as ↑ ↓ ↑ ↓ along all directions; thus, the ground state is a fully compensated antiferromagnet.
elements.clean_text: An answer to the final question regarding the type of long-range magnetic order is related to the sequence of the two moment carriers in the lattice. When the sequence is ⋅⋅⋅Cr-Mn-Cr-Mn⋅⋅⋅ in two or three dimension, as is the case for all  previously studied systems,  the ground state is ferrimagnetic, meaning a magnetic order ↑    ↓   ↑    ↓    (where ↑ and     ↓    represent the moment vector of Cr (3 μB) and Mn (5 μB), respectively). For the present compound the sequence is⋅⋅⋅Cr-Mn-Mn-Cr⋅⋅⋅, and for an all AF couplings of the moments will arrange as ↑    ↓   ↑    ↓    along all directions; thus, the ground state is a fully compensated antiferromagnet.

elements.content: K3[Mn­(l-asp)]6[Cr­(CN)6]·2H2O, obtained by self-assembly of the individual components, Mn2+, K+, asp2–, and [Cr­(CN)6]3–, contains the generic code of the chirality of the organic ligand, where all its five coordinating atoms (4 O and 1 N) are connected to the Mn2+. It has the highest ratio of Mn to Cr of 6:1 and a novel structural topology with a···Cr–Mn–Mn–Cr··· sequence within the 3D framework instead of···Cr–Mn–Cr–Mn··· and resulted in the first antiferromagnet for this series of materials. The long-range AF order is unusual for (a) the susceptibility is temperature independent below T N and (b) the FC magnetization bifurcates from the FC one below T N. The first anomaly is associated with nonlinear alignment of the moments leading to the proposal of a conic or helical magnetic structure that also satisfies the linear dependence of the isothermal magnetization. The second is due to the presence of domains that are derived from the large number of magnetic sublattices of 42 in the simplest case. The low Néel temperature of 4.5 K is due to the low CN–Mn angle of 133° and 145° compared to the highest T C of 90 K when the angle is 180°. The present work demonstrates the importance of the organic ligand where the number of coordinating atoms is responsible for the structural topology and consequently the magnetic state. Further works are in progress in this development in order to get a further structure–property relationship that can lead to potential new physics.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

K3[Mn(l-asp)]6[Cr(CN)6]⋅2H2O, obtained by self-assembly of the individual components, Mn2+, K+, asp2-, and [Cr(CN)6]3-, contains the generic code of the chirality of the organic ligand, where all its five coordinating atoms (4 O and 1 N) are connected to the Mn2+. It has the highest ratio of Mn to Cr of 6:1 and a novel structural topology with a⋅⋅⋅Cr-Mn-Mn-Cr⋅⋅⋅ sequence within the 3D framework instead of⋅⋅⋅Cr-Mn-Cr-Mn⋅⋅⋅ and resulted in the first antiferromagnet for this series of materials. The long-range AF order is unusual for (a) the susceptibility is temperature independent below T N and (b) the FC magnetization bifurcates from the FC one below T N. The first anomaly is associated with nonlinear alignment of the moments leading to the proposal of a conic or helical magnetic structure that also satisfies the linear dependence of the isothermal magnetization. The second is due to the presence of domains that are derived from the large number of magnetic sublattices of 42 in the simplest case. The low Néel temperature of 4.5 K is due to the low CN-Mn angle of 133° and 145° compared to the highest T C of 90 K when the angle is 180°. The present work demonstrates the importance of the organic ligand where the number of coordinating atoms is responsible for the structural topology and consequently the magnetic state. Further works are in progress in this development in order to get a further structure-property relationship that can lead to potential new physics.

cln_elements.content: All manipulations were performed under an argon atmosphere to avoid the oxidation of MnII ions. Crystals of K3[Mn­(l-asp)]6[Cr­(CN)6]·2H2O were prepared by slow diffusion as follows: 1 mL of an aqueous solution of l-aspartic acid (2 mmol), KOH (3.2 mmol), and K3[Cr­(CN)6] (0.1 mmol) was placed in a 25 cm long glass tube (ϕ = 5 mm) followed by 1 mL of a H2O:EtOH (3:1) mixture as buffer and a top layer of a solution of 1.5 mL of H2O:EtOH (1:3) containing MnCl2·4H2O (3 mmol). After 2 months, undisturbed in the dark, orange hexagonal prism crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiment were obtained. Anal. Calcd for K3[Mn­(l-asp)]6[Cr­(CN)6]·2H2O, C30H34CrK3Mn6N12O26: C, 24.39; H, 2.32; N, 11.38. Found: C, 23.80; H, 2.04; N, 11.86.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All manipulations were performed under an argon atmosphere to avoid the oxidation of MnII ions. Crystals of K3[Mn(l-asp)]6[Cr(CN)6]⋅2H2O were prepared by slow diffusion as follows: 1 mL of an aqueous solution of l-aspartic acid (2 mmol), KOH (3.2 mmol), and K3[Cr(CN)6] (0.1 mmol) was placed in a 25 cm long glass tube (ϕ = 5 mm) followed by 1 mL of a H2O:EtOH (3:1) mixture as buffer and a top layer of a solution of 1.5 mL of H2O:EtOH (1:3) containing MnCl2⋅4H2O (3 mmol). After 2 months, undisturbed in the dark, orange hexagonal prism crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiment were obtained. Anal. Calcd for K3[Mn(l-asp)]6[Cr(CN)6]⋅2H2O, C30H34CrK3Mn6N12O26: C, 24.39; H, 2.32; N, 11.38. Found: C, 23.80; H, 2.04; N, 11.86.

cln_elements.content: The thermogravimetric analysis on heating under a flow of dry nitrogen shows almost a constant weight until 100 °C followed by a loss of two water molecules per mole by 220 °C (Figure S1). Between 220 and 320 °C the loss of weight amounts to the departure of the aspartate. Further heating leads to continuous weight loss. The observed loss of two water molecules was helpful in the final refinement of the X-ray crystal structure determination that accounts for the remaining electron density after the metal–cyanide framework was established.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Property

The thermogravimetric analysis on heating under a flow of dry nitrogen shows almost a constant weight until 100 °C followed by a loss of two water molecules per mole by 220 °C (Figure S1). Between 220 and 320 °C the loss of weight amounts to the departure of the aspartate. Further heating leads to continuous weight loss. The observed loss of two water molecules was helpful in the final refinement of the X-ray crystal structure determination that accounts for the remaining electron density after the metal-cyanide framework was established.

cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Field dependence isothermal magnetization of K3[Mn(l-asp)]6[Cr(CN)6]⋅2H2O above (5 and 10 K) and below (2 K)  T Néel (4.5 K). Solid lines are the magnetization calculated by the Brillouin function for S = 27/2 (blue) and six isolated Mn2+ ions and one Cr3+ ion (gray) at 2 K.

metadata.title:
